Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Hispanic Population Growth and Black-White Relations in the United States

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1333561
Miguel Centeno
Maria C. Abascal
Princeton University

How will the introduction of a third, major ethnoracial group affect relations between pre-existing ethnoracial groups? This dissertation broaches this question through the lens of Hispanic population growth and its impact on black/white relations in the United States. The black/white divide has characterized US race relations for most of the country's history; Hispanics are changing that through high birth rates and continued immigration. This project examines the impact of real and perceived levels of Hispanic population growth on Blacks' and Whites' attitudes toward each other and their support for race-targeted and race-coded policies, like affirmative action and welfare. Previous research hints at two possible outcomes of Hispanic population growth: 1) the reinforcement of a black-nonblack divide; or 2) the merger of Blacks and Whites along a shared (American) identity that excludes Hispanics on the basis of cultural rather than racial differences. The study analyzes nationally representative survey data along with original experimental data to address these questions. An analysis of trend data from the General Social Survey and the American National Election Studies data documents how Blacks' and Whites' racial and policy attitudes change over time and in response to local levels of Hispanic population growth. Public goods games will be conducted to extend survey findings to observable behaviors in a controlled laboratory setting. By manipulating two aspects of the game (participants' perceptions of Hispanic population growth and the racial composition of the game group, the games examine whether Blacks' and Whites' contributions to a racially-mixed group vary in response to perceived population trends.

Broader Impacts

As public disagreement over the role of government grows, Americans' racial and policy attitudes and the future of the American welfare state become important topics of both academic and public policy concern. This is especially true in the context of substantial Hispanic population growth, which is no longer limited to a handful of immigration gateways. The recent shift toward new destinations of immigration compels scholars to examine the impact of diversification in communities without established immigrant or minority populations. Research findings have important implications for social policy, including: 1) predicting sites of racial/ethnic hostility, and 2) detailing the impact of diversification on public support for policies like affirmative action and welfare. The study will yield practical information about the value of experimental game methods for the study of race relations. Accordingly, the experimental protocol and data (with identifying information removed) from the games will be made available online, and thus publicly accessible. The findings of this research will be disseminated via interdisciplinary journals and conferences, facilitated in part by ongoing affiliations with the Princeton University Center for Migration and Development and the Center for the Study of Social Organization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Historically, the United States has been home to two, major racial/ethnic groups: Blacks and Whites. However, the United States is also in the midst of radical demographic transformation driven largely by the growth of the Hispanic population. Understanding how Hispanic growth will alter the pre-existing system of black-white relations requires drawing on theoretical tools that have not yet been developed. This is because research on group relations has typically focused on two groups in isolation – e.g., men and women, blacks and whites, blue- and brown-eyed children. As a result, past research gives us few clues into how relations play out in multi-group contexts.

 

The goals of this project were twofold: 1) to move past the “two-group paradigm” that characterizes theoretical and empirical work on group relations, in order to 2) shed light on whether and how Hispanic growth—real and perceived—affects relations between Blacks and Whites. The investigator used a series of strategies to explore these questions, including a laboratory experiment, a field experiment carried out in airport waiting areas, and the analysis of responses to two national social surveys.

 

The results of the project suggest that Blacks and Whites react in different ways to the perception of Hispanic growth. Whites who are exposed to Hispanic growth identify relatively more strongly with their racial group (other Whites) and they are relatively more generous to Whites than Blacks (in the context of an experimental game). Blacks, on the other hand, identify relatively more strongly with their national group (other Americans) and they are equally generous toward Blacks and Whites. The results suggest that people respond to the growth of a third group by prioritizing the most privileged identity they can plausibly claim and which also excludes the growing group. For Whites, this is their whiteness; for Blacks, this is their Americanness.

 

The results of this experiment were published in the August 2015 issue of American Sociological Review. They have been presented to a range of interdisciplinary audiences. The investigator is also working on writing up the results from an extension of the experiment she ran in airport waiting areas, along with the results from the national surveys. In the meantime, she is posting anonymized data and protocols from the experiment to an online repository in order to encourage and facilitate the use of similar methods among other sociologists. She is also drawing on her experience with this project to develop a course on experimental methods in the social sciences.
